title: Malala’s Magic Pencil
author: Malala Yousafzai
summary: Malala, a little girl from Pakistan, had always wanted to have a magic pencil that could change the world around her. Even though she never found the pencil, she realised that her words could make an impact. This book encourages everyone to use their voices and powers to help change the world around them.

discussion_questions: Have you ever heard of the girl named Malala?
Based on the cover of the book, can you guess what this book will be about?
pre.homework: Find out who Malala is as preparation for the listening/reading task.

discussion_questions: Discuss why it is important to go to school and what makes the school so special.
Discuss how Malala’s wishes changed from wanting small things to wanting to change the world around her.
creative: Draw your own magic pencil that can change the world.
Write about what you would do if you had a 'magic' pencil.
other: Recall times when you did something good for someone or stood up for someone.

title: All Are Welcome
author: Alexandra Penfold
summary: This book demonstrates that regardless of one's background, everyone is welcome. It shows different cultural and social backgrounds and encourages acceptance, kindness, and inclusivity.

discussion_questions: Can you guess what this book will be about based on its cover and title?
What can you notice about the children on the cover of the book?
What does being 'welcomed' mean to you?
What did you like about the book?
What differences do the children in the book have?
What does it mean to feel 'welcomed'?
What can we do to make someone feel 'welcomed'?
creative: In groups, make a poster where children write what they can do to make each other feel 'welcomed'.
Individually, make a poster of yourself and write around your portrait what makes you unique, then share it with others.

title: The Proudest Blue: A Story of Hijab and a Family
author: Ibtihaj Muhammad with S.K. Ali
publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
summary: It is Faizah’s first day of school and her sister Asiya’s first day wearing a hijab. Faizah is proud of her sister, viewing her as a princess, even though not everyone sees it that way. This book celebrates diversity, family, and strength.

title: Frida Kahlo
author: Isabel Sanchez Vegara
summary: This book tells the story of Frida Kahlo, a young woman from Mexico who, despite fragile health, never gave up on her art and remained positive. It introduces children to Mexican culture and inspires perseverance.

title: Last Stop on Market Street
author: Matt de la Peña
publisher: G.P. Putnam's Sons Books for Young Readers
summary: A young boy named CJ walks with his grandmother and learns to be grateful and to see beauty in everything. The book highlights diversity and teaches appreciation beyond material things.

title: Not Quite Narwhal
author: Jessie Sima
publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
summary: Kelp, a young narwhal, realises he doesn't quite fit in. After discovering he is a unicorn, he learns that he is accepted by both groups. A story about self-discovery and acceptance.

title: The Great Henna Party
author: Humera Malik
summary: Noor’s cousin is getting married, and she plays a henna name game but faces a dilemma—how to choose one name when she loves everyone? The story celebrates South Asian culture, family, and community.

title: I Am Enough
author: Grace Byers
summary: This is a book to remind students that, no matter their differences, they are enough just the way they are.

title: The Black Book of Colours
author: Menena Cottin and Rosana Faría
summary: This book explores how a child who cannot see experiences different colours through other senses. It features Braille and textures and offers a unique way of perceiving the world.

title: Baby Goes to Market
author: Atinuke
summary: With a baby strapped to her back, Mama goes to the West African market to buy food. Without her notice, the baby puts different foods into the basket. This picture book showcases the bustling streets of West Africa and introduces young readers to a different culture through colourful illustrations.
